creator: andreas.berg@triona.de
text:
log4j.properties:

#First Appender
log4j.appender.OneFileout=org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender
log4j.appender.OneFileout.File=c:/temp/one.log
log4j.appender.OneFileout.MaxFileSize=1000KB
log4j.appender.OneFileout.MaxBackupIndex=1
log4j.appender.OneFileout.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
log4j.appender.OneFileout.layout.ConversionPattern=%5p;%c{3};%d{ISO8601};[%t];%
m%n

#Second Appender
log4j.appender.TwoFileout=org.apache.log4j.RollingFileAppender
log4j.appender.TwoFileout.File=c:/temp/two.log
log4j.appender.TwoFileout.MaxFileSize=1000KB
log4j.appender.TwoFileout.MaxBackupIndex=1
log4j.appender.TwoFileout.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
log4j.appender.TwoFileout.layout.ConversionPattern=%5p;%c{3};%d{ISO8601};[%t];%
m%n

log4j.logger.foo = FATAL, OneFileout
log4j.logger.foo.bar = DEBUG, TwoFileout

The call "Logger.getLogger("foo.bar").debug("Hello World");" writes to one.log 
AND two.log, it should only write to two.log, because only FATAL messages 
should go to OneFileout.

Or am I wrong? Kind regards,

Andreas.

creator: paul.smith@lawlex.com.au
text:
You're missing the vital bit of information that Loggers are an inherited 
hierarchy.  

Loggers are a tree hierachy, and Logger 'foo' is a logical parent Logger of 
'foo.bar'.  log4j first sends a LoggingEvent to the requested Logger (say 'foo.
bar'), which will go to 'Twofileout', BUT the event is then propagated up the 
Logger hierarchy to the root Logger, and on the way, it passes through the 'foo' 
logger, and of course will go into the 'Onefileout' appender.

If you do not wish for this to happen, you will need to configure the 
"additivity" property for the 'foo.bar' Logger to be 'false' so that log4j stops 
propagating the event up the hierarchy.
